<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/07/football-season-back-xfl-return?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Are You Ready for Some Football?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="In this graphic, an XFL helmet is attached to a television set" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxMTEyNTI5LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When the XFL crashed and burned in 2001, our nine-year-old selves were not expecting our 28-year-old selves to be writing about the XFL. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But capitalism is relentless.</strong> This afternoon, the new football league owned by billionaire wrestling exec Vince McMahon will play its first games. Of course, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/05/sports/football/xfl-preview.html?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports&stream=top&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">today’s XFL</a> bears almost no resemblance to the wildly violent and raunchy first edition, which unironically fielded a team called the Hitmen. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Instead, viewers will be treated to fast-paced, rule-heavy football games that focus on quality, not spectacle. However, it’s still not clear whether the XFL will become a viable enterprise. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Why the XFL might work </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Sports betting: </strong>The new XFL is a gambler’s playground. ABC and ESPN’s coverage this weekend will <a href="https://frntofficesport.com/xfl-espn-abc-betting-lines/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports&stream=top&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">feature point spreads</a> and over/unders on their “score bugs” (the graphics at the bottom showing the score). And TV commentators can talk about those bets when appropriate, something they’re not allowed to do calling NFL games.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>As sports betting breaks free from its regulatory shackles, the size of the industry is starting to take shape. Last week, casino operator Penn National Gaming paid $163 million for a </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/29/penn-national-gaming-buys-stake-values-barstool-sports-450-million?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">36% stake</a></span><span> in Barstool Sports, a media company with a rabid audience of sports bettors. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Television: </strong>Every single XFL game will be aired on networks such as ABC, ESPN, and FOX. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Product: </strong>The games are expected to take less than three hours. Please let this be true. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Why the XFL might not work </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The list of failed NFL wannabee leagues is longer than a CVS receipt. The most recent entry was the Alliance of American Football, which went <a href="https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/26957796/inside-short-unhappy-life-alliance-american-football?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">bankrupt</a> last year after a nasty, brutish, and short life. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>whatever happens with the XFL long-term, Vince McMahon is glad for the distraction. WWE, the sports entertainment company he leads, expressed “<a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/06/investing/wwe-earnings-stock/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">considerable uncertainty</a>” about its outlook and strategy this week. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F02%2F07%2Ffootball-season-back-xfl-return" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/07/coronavirus-updates-fed-autos-apparel?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Coronavirus Updates
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="In this photo, a person in China walks through an industrial lot wearing a surgical mask." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/35/Mercado_de_mariscos_de_Wuhan_cerrado_tras_detectarse_ahi_por_primera_vez_el_Nuevo_Coronavirus_.jpg">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>SISTEMA 12, Mercado de mariscos de Wuhan cerrado tras detectarse ahi por primera vez el Nuevo Coronavirus , <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/legalcode" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CC BY-SA 4.0</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The coronavirus that originated in Wuhan, China, is continuing its assault on the global economy. In its semiannual report to Congress yesterday, the Fed warned that the outbreak presents a “<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-07/fed-warns-virus-poses-new-risk-to-global-growth-and-markets?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new risk</a>” to the <span>economic outlook for the U.S.</span></p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Sector by sector</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Auto: </strong>Carmakers are being <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/07/business/coronavirus-china-auto-factories.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">squeezed on all sides</a>. Not only are sales getting whacked in China, the world’s largest auto market, but their supply chains are being thrown into chaos as Chinese factories remain shut down.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Tourism: </strong>“Hotels and travel agencies catering to Chinese have seen what one employee in Rome called a 'bloodbath' of cancellations,” <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/coronavirus-as-chinese-tourists-stay-home-a-world-that-has-grown-dependent-on-them-feels-their-absence/2020/02/07/0ff7a37e-46a4-11ea-91ab-ce439aa5c7c1_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes the WaPo</a>. Chinese travelers account for more than 10% of the global tourism industry, but they’ve been staying home.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Apparel: </strong>Luxury parka maker Canada Goose <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/07/investing/canada-goose-coronavirus-china-earnings/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">warned yesterday</a> that the “<span>health crisis has resulted in a sharp decline in customer traffic and purchasing activity</span>.” Shares fell over 4%.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>World Health Organization officials said the number of new coronavirus cases <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/07/coronavirus-cases-slow-in-china-but-its-way-too-early-to-celebrate-who.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">slowed</a> in China for a second day on Friday, but it’s too early to tell whether that’s a trend or a blip.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TELECOM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/07/us-invest-nordic-telecoms-battle-huawei?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
A Million Huaweis to Win in the West
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Huawei logo " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxMTA1ODg1LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For all the feats of American ingenuity (March Madness, the Roomba, Jell-O salad), there’s one big thing we can’t nail: a homegrown rival to take on China’s Huawei in 5G technology.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s why Attorney General William Barr <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-espionage/to-counter-huawei-us-could-take-controlling-stake-in-ericsson-nokia-attorney-general-idUSKBN2001DL?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">urged the U.S.</a> to invest in Huawei’s only real competition, Sweden’s Ericsson and Finland’s Nokia. FYI, the U.S. doesn’t usually make investments like this.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Barr suggested in a speech on Thursday that the U.S. take a "controlling stake" in one or both of the Nordic firms.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“Putting our large market and financial muscle behind one or both of these firms would make it a more formidable competitor,” Barr said. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>What that might look like, per the NYT’s DealBook: a U.S. telecom or private equity consortium makes a bid for Nokia/Ericsson </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/07/business/dealbook/bill-barr-huawei-nokia-ericsson.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">in exchange for</a></span><span> tax breaks or subsidies from the government.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Huawei, which the U.S. views as a Trojan Horse for Chinese spies, sells just under one-third of the <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/1aa61918-48fc-11ea-aeb3-955839e06441?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">world’s telecom equipment</a>. The U.S. controlling Nokia or Ericsson would loosen Huawei's stranglehold on the market, but the plan is highly unusual.</p>

C-SUITE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/02/07/execs-coming-going-prison-friday?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The C-Suite Chronicles, Ep. 423: Someone Goes to Prison
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="PIMCO offices " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTgxMTEwNzA3LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mark Boster/Los Angeles Times via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">At Ford? </strong>No, but one of the two presidents considered next in line for the CEO position, Jim Farley, will become Ford’s COO, while the other, Joe Hinrichs, will retire.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Ford leadership has </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-07/ford-promotes-one-president-as-another-retires-amid-profit-slump?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">struggled to execute</a></span><span> a turnaround, pushing investor patience. This surprise shakeup, which came three days after disappointing Ford Q4 results, shows just how impatient they’ve become.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">At Credit Suisse? </strong>No, but it’s in damage control mode. The Swiss lender <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/07/business/credit-suisse-ceo-resigns/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ousted CEO Tidjane Thiam</a> to sweep up the debris from two spying scandals.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>One of those scandals: After a top Credit Suisse exec left for a job at rival UBS, one of Thiam’s top reports hired detectives to follow the turncoat. That opened a Pandora’s box of culture issues Credit Suisse hasn’t been able to resolve.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">At Pimco? </strong>Nailed it. The bond giant’s ex-CEO, Douglas Hodge, was <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-pimco-ceo-to-be-sentenced-in-college-admissions-scandal-11581089874?mod=hp_lead_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sentenced to nine months in prison</a> for his involvement in last year’s college admissions cheating scandal.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Hodge paid $850,000 for preferential treatment, the most of any of the 36 parents charged. So far, that's the longest sentence of the crew. </span></li>
</ul>

</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Many of you prefer your local cuisine.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Even if you didn't win a MacBook Pro this week, you still have Saturday Headlines to look forward to. Here are three real stories from the week's news and one we made up out of thin air. Can you spot the fake? </p>

</li>

<span>“</span><span><a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/l2Jeal95KEUTLzNpS/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Paper crumbs</a></span><span> of Nancy Pelosi’s State of the Union address wind up on eBay for $1.5 million” </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Flyers mascot Gritty </span><span><a href="https://www.espn.com/nhl/story/_/id/28626947/flyers-mascot-cleared-wrongdoing-alleged-assault-case?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cleared of any wrongdoing</a></span><span><span> in alleged assault” </span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“</span><span><a href="https://nypost.com/2020/02/03/iowa-caucuses-attendee-drops-breaks-concealed-bottle-of-wine-at-polling-site/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Iowa caucuses</a></span><span><span>: Attendee drops, breaks ‘concealed bottle of wine’”</span></span><span>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen the XFL crashed and burned in 2001, our nine-year-old selves were not expecting our 28-year-old selves to be writing about the XFL. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut capitalism is relentless.\u003c/strong\u003e This afternoon, the new football league owned by billionaire wrestling exec Vince McMahon will play its first games. Of course, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/05/sports/football/xfl-preview.html?utm_source=newsletter\u0026utm_medium=email\u0026utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports\u0026stream=top\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etoday’s XFL\u003c/a\u003e bears almost no resemblance to the wildly violent and raunchy first edition, which unironically fielded a team called the Hitmen. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInstead, viewers will be treated to fast-paced, rule-heavy football games that focus on quality, not spectacle. However, it’s still not clear whether the XFL will become a viable enterprise. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhy the XFL might work \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSports betting: \u003c/strong\u003eThe new XFL is a gambler’s playground. ABC and ESPN’s coverage this weekend will \u003ca href=\"https://frntofficesport.com/xfl-espn-abc-betting-lines/?utm_source=newsletter\u0026utm_medium=email\u0026utm_campaign=newsletter_axiossports\u0026stream=top\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efeature point spreads\u003c/a\u003e and over/unders on their “score bugs” (the graphics at the bottom showing the score). And TV commentators can talk about those bets when appropriate, something they’re not allowed to do calling NFL games.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAs sports betting breaks free from its regulatory shackles, the size of the industry is starting to take shape. Last week, casino operator Penn National Gaming paid $163 million for a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/29/penn-national-gaming-buys-stake-values-barstool-sports-450-million?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e36% stake\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in Barstool Sports, a media company with a rabid audience of sports bettors. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTelevision: \u003c/strong\u003eEvery single XFL game will be aired on networks such as ABC, ESPN, and FOX. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eProduct: \u003c/strong\u003eThe games are expected to take less than three hours. Please let this be true. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhy the XFL might not work \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe list of failed NFL wannabee leagues is longer than a CVS receipt. The most recent entry was the Alliance of American Football, which went \u003ca href=\"https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/26957796/inside-short-unhappy-life-alliance-american-football?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebankrupt\u003c/a\u003e last year after a nasty, brutish, and short life. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ewhatever happens with the XFL long-term, Vince McMahon is glad for the distraction. WWE, the sports entertainment company he leads, expressed “\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/06/investing/wwe-earnings-stock/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econsiderable uncertainty\u003c/a\u003e” about its outlook and strategy this week. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe coronavirus that originated in Wuhan, China, is continuing its assault on the global economy. In its semiannual report to Congress yesterday, the Fed warned that the outbreak presents a “\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-07/fed-warns-virus-poses-new-risk-to-global-growth-and-markets?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew risk\u003c/a\u003e” to the \u003cspan\u003eeconomic outlook for the U.S.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSector by sector\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAuto: \u003c/strong\u003eCarmakers are being \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/07/business/coronavirus-china-auto-factories.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esqueezed on all sides\u003c/a\u003e. Not only are sales getting whacked in China, the world’s largest auto market, but their supply chains are being thrown into chaos as Chinese factories remain shut down.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTourism: \u003c/strong\u003e“Hotels and travel agencies catering to Chinese have seen what one employee in Rome called a 'bloodbath' of cancellations,” \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/coronavirus-as-chinese-tourists-stay-home-a-world-that-has-grown-dependent-on-them-feels-their-absence/2020/02/07/0ff7a37e-46a4-11ea-91ab-ce439aa5c7c1_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites the WaPo\u003c/a\u003e. Chinese travelers account for more than 10% of the global tourism industry, but they’ve been staying home.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eApparel: \u003c/strong\u003eLuxury parka maker Canada Goose \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/07/investing/canada-goose-coronavirus-china-earnings/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewarned yesterday\u003c/a\u003e that the “\u003cspan\u003ehealth crisis has resulted in a sharp decline in customer traffic and purchasing activity\u003c/span\u003e.” Shares fell over 4%.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eWorld Health Organization officials said the number of new coronavirus cases \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/07/coronavirus-cases-slow-in-china-but-its-way-too-early-to-celebrate-who.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eslowed\u003c/a\u003e in China for a second day on Friday, but it’s too early to tell whether that’s a trend or a Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor all the feats of American ingenuity (March Madness, the Roomba, Jell-O salad), there’s one big thing we can’t nail: a homegrown rival to take on China’s Huawei in 5G technology.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s why Attorney General William Barr \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-espionage/to-counter-huawei-us-could-take-controlling-stake-in-ericsson-nokia-attorney-general-idUSKBN2001DL?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eurged the U.S.\u003c/a\u003e to invest in Huawei’s only real competition, Sweden’s Ericsson and Finland’s Nokia. FYI, the U.S. doesn’t usually make investments like this.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBarr suggested in a speech on Thursday that the U.S. take a \"controlling stake\" in one or both of the Nordic firms.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“Putting our large market and financial muscle behind one or both of these firms would make it a more formidable competitor,” Barr said. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eWhat that might look like, per the NYT’s DealBook: a U.S. telecom or private equity consortium makes a bid for Nokia/Ericsson \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/07/business/dealbook/bill-barr-huawei-nokia-ericsson.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ein exchange for\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e tax breaks or subsidies from the government.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eHuawei, which the U.S. views as a Trojan Horse for Chinese spies, sells just under one-third of the \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/1aa61918-48fc-11ea-aeb3-955839e06441?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eworld’s telecom equipment\u003c/a\u003e. The U.S. controlling Nokia or Ericsson would loosen Huawei's stranglehold on the market, but the plan is highly unusual.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAt Ford? \u003c/strong\u003eNo, but one of the two presidents considered next in line for the CEO position, Jim Farley, will become Ford’s COO, while the other, Joe Hinrichs, will retire.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFord leadership has \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-07/ford-promotes-one-president-as-another-retires-amid-profit-slump?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estruggled to execute\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a turnaround, pushing investor patience. This surprise shakeup, which came three days after disappointing Ford Q4 results, shows just how impatient they’ve become.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAt Credit Suisse? \u003c/strong\u003eNo, but it’s in damage control mode. The Swiss lender \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/07/business/credit-suisse-ceo-resigns/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eousted CEO Tidjane Thiam\u003c/a\u003e to sweep up the debris from two spying scandals.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOne of those scandals: After a top Credit Suisse exec left for a job at rival UBS, one of Thiam’s top reports hired detectives to follow the turncoat. That opened a Pandora’s box of culture issues Credit Suisse hasn’t been able to resolve.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAt Pimco? \u003c/strong\u003eNailed it. The bond giant’s ex-CEO, Douglas Hodge, was \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-pimco-ceo-to-be-sentenced-in-college-admissions-scandal-11581089874?mod=hp_lead_pos4\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esentenced to nine months in prison\u003c/a\u003e for his involvement in last year’s college admissions cheating scandal.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHodge paid $850,000 for preferential treatment, the most of any of the 36 parents charged.
